facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 213 of 1967 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 213 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and order dated February 17th 1965 of Patna High Court in First Appeal No. 113 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated February, 17th 1965 of the Patna High Court in First Appeal No. 113 of 1960.

facts.text: Will executed by Raghunath Prasad Singh on August 31, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by certificate we are to companysider the effect of the will executed by one Raghunath Prasad Singh, on August 31, 1938.

facts.text: Testator died very soon after execution of the will.

anchor.surface_text: The said testator died very soon after the execution of the will leaving behind him his widow Jageshwar Kuer,

facts.text: Testator survived by widow Jageshwar Kuer, daughter Satrupa Kuer, and granddaughters Talkeshwari Devi (appellant) and Sheorani.

anchor.surface_text: leaving behind him his widow Jageshwar Kuer, his daughter Satrupa Kuer and his two grand daughters Talkeshwari Devi  the appellant herein  and Sheorani.

facts.text: Appellant Talkeshwari Devi and Sheorani are daughters of Sukhdeo Prasad Singh, son of testator who predeceased him.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and Sheorani are the daughters of Sukhdeo Prasad Singh, the son of the testator who had predeceased the testator.

facts.text: Jageshwar Kuer died in November 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Jageshwar Kuer died in November 1948 and Sheorani Devi on November 1, 1949

facts.text: Sheorani Devi died on November 1, 1949 without leaving any issue.

anchor.surface_text: and Sheorani Devi on November 1, 1949 without leaving any issue. The dispute in this case is as to who

facts.text: Dispute concerns who is entitled to properties devolved on Sheorani under the will.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute in this case is as to who is entitled to the properties devolved on Sheorani under the provisions of the will left by the testator.

facts.text: Genuineness or validity of the will not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: the genuineness or validity of which is number in dispute. The will in question provides that after

facts.text: Will provides portion of properties devolve absolutely on Jageshwar Kuer after testator's death.

anchor.surface_text: The will in question provides that after the death of the testator a portion of his properties  detailed in the will  was to devolve on Jageshwar Kuer absolutely

facts.text: Remaining properties devolve on Jageshwar Kuer with life interest.

anchor.surface_text: and the remaining properties are also to devolve on her but therein she was to have only a life interest.

facts.text: After Jageshwar's death, 5 annas 4 pies share to Satrupa Kuer and heirs absolutely.

anchor.surface_text: The will further provides that after her death the entire property will be treated as 16 annas property out of which 5 annas 4 pies five annas four pies  share companystituting proprietary interest will pass to Shrimati Satrupa Kuer alias Nan daughter of me, the executant and her heirs as absolute owners

facts.text: After Jageshwar's death, 10 annas 8 pies share to granddaughters Talkeshwari and Sheorani in equal shares absolutely (clause 4).

anchor.surface_text: and the remaining 10 annas 8 pies  annas ten and eight pies  share will pass to both the minor grand daughters,  1  Shrimati Talkeshwari Kuer alias Babu and  2  Shrimati Sheorani Kuer alias Bachan in equal shares as absolute proprietary interest  cf. 4 of the will .

facts.text: Clause 5 of will: if one granddaughter dies issueless, other gets entire 10 annas 8 pies absolutely.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 5 of the will says That if one of the two grand daughters named above, dies issueless, then under such circumstances the other living grand daughter will enter into possession and occupation of the entire 10 annas 8 pies and become the absolute owner thereof.

facts.text: At testator's death, appellant and Sheorani were minors.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the death of the testator, the appellant as well as Sheorani Kuer were minors.

facts.text: After Jageshwar Kuer's death, appellant and Sheorani divided 10 annas 8 pies share equally and took possession.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Jageshwar Kuer, the appellant and her sister Sheorani Kuer divided the ten annas eight pies share of the properties which devolved on them in equal shares and each one came into possession of her share of the properties.

facts.text: Immediately after Sheorani's death, appellant instituted suit for possession of Sheorani's share based on clause 5.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately after the death of Sheorani Kuer, the appellant instituted a suit for possession of the properties that fell to the share of Sheorani Kuer purporting to base her claim on clause 5 of the will to which we have earlier made reference.

facts.text: Suit resisted by first defendant, husband of Sheorani, claiming as her heir.

anchor.surface_text: That suit was resisted by the first defendant, the husband of Sheorani. He claimed that he was entitled to those properties as the heir of his wife.

facts.text: Trial court dismissed plaintiff's suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt dismissed the plaintiffs suit and the decision of the trial companyrt

facts.text: Patna High Court upheld trial court's decision.

anchor.surface_text: was upheld by the High Court. It was companytended on behalf of the appellant that in view of clause 5

facts.text: Appellant claimed entitled to suit properties under clause 5 as Sheorani died issueless.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended on behalf of the appellant that in view of clause 5 of the will, the appellant is entitled to the suit properties as Sheorani Kuer had died issueless.

facts.text: Trial court and High Court held clause 5 ceased to operate after Jageshwar's death; clause 4 gives absolute estate to granddaughters.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention, as mentioned earlier, did number find favour either with the trial companyrt or with the appellate companyrt. They have held that on a proper leading of the will as a whole, it is clear that clause 5 ceased to be operative on the death of Jageshwar Kuer, thereafter caluse 4 of the will was the only operative clause so far as the rights of the appellant and Sheorani ware companycerned.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with lower courts that suit is unsustainable.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above we are in agreement with the companyrts below that the suit brought by the appellant is un- sustainable.

It is undisputed that the duty of the court is to find out the intention of the testator but that intention has to be gathered from the language of the will read as a whole. I is clear from clause 4 of the will that the testator wanted to give to his grant-daughters an absolute right in the properties that were to devolve on them after the death of his wife, Jageshwar Kuer.

concepts.interpretation: Intention gathered from language of will read as whole; clear from clause 4 absolute right given, clause 5 relates to devolution not divestment.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: whole, it is clear that clause 5 ceased to be operative on the death of Jageshwar Kuer, thereafter caluse 4 of the will was the only operative clause

concepts.unlisted_label: Testator's Intention from Will as Whole
concepts.unlisted_description: Principle that court ascertains testator's intention from language of entire will.

anchor.surface_text: I is clear from clause 4 of the will that the testator wanted to give to his grant-daughters an absolute right in the properties that were to devolve on them after the death of his wife, Jageshwar Kuer. The estate bequeathed under clause 4 of the will is number a conditional estate.

concepts.interpretation: Estate under clause 4 is absolute, not conditional; vested absolutely on granddaughters after Jageshwar's death.

concepts.unlisted_description: Unconditional ownership in property bequeathed by will.

concepts.interpretation: Clause 5 is not a defeasance clause as it does not provide for divestment of vested absolute estate.

concepts.unlisted_description: Clause providing for divestment of vested estate on occurrence of contingency.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 5 of the will relates to devolution and it does number provide for any divestment of an estate which had vested. The estate that vested on Sheorani was an absolute one. The will does number provide for the divestment of that estate.

concepts.interpretation: Distinction between devolution (vesting on death of life tenant) and divestment (loss of vested estate); clause 5 concerns devolution before vesting.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: he will relates to devolution and it does number provide for any divestment of an estate which had vested. The estate that vested on Sheorani was an a

concepts.unlisted_label: Devolution vs Divestment of Vested Estate
concepts.unlisted_description: Legal principles distinguishing property passing on death from loss of already vested property rights.

anchor.surface_text: Section 124 says Where a legacy is given if a specified uncertain event shall happen and numbertime is mentioned in the will for be occurrence of that event, the legacy cannot take effect, unless such event happens before the period when the fund bequeathed is payable or distributable. -L864 Sup.CI/72 Illustration  ii  to that section says A legacy is bequeathed to A, and in the case of his death without children, to B.

concepts.interpretation: Applies to facts; legacy to appellant unavailable as contingency (death issueless) did not happen before properties distributable after Jageshwar's death.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ii  to that section says A legacy is bequeathed to A, and in the case of his death without children, to B. If A survives the testator or dies in his

concepts.unlisted_description: Contingent legacies on uncertain events must occur before distribution.

anchor.surface_text: That section says A bequest may be made to any person with the condition super added that, in case a specified uncertain event shall happen, the thing bequeathed shall go to another person, or that in case a specified uncertain event shall number happen, the thing bequeathed shall go over to another person.

concepts.interpretation: Governing provision contended by appellant but not applicable as no divestment of vested estate; clause 5 not such condition.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ber take effect. If s. 124 applies to the facts of the case, as we think it does, then it is clear that the legacy claimed by the appellant is unavail

concepts.unlisted_description: Conditional bequests with superadded conditions for going over on uncertain events.

anchor.surface_text: To find out the effect of the will before us we have to look to ss. 1-4 and 131 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provisions applied to interpret will's effect.

anchor.surface_text: In arriving at this conclusion, the Judicial Committee relied on s. 111 of the Indian Succession Act, 1865. That provision is similar to s. 124 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925.

concepts.interpretation: Similar to s.124 ISA 1925; applied in Privy Council case similar to present.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the appellant that in view of clause 5 of the will, the appellant is entitled to the suit properties as Sheorani Kuer had died issueless.

arguments.court_reasoning: Clause 5 relates to devolution before vesting of absolute estate under clause 4; did not find favour with trial court, high court, or Supreme Court

arguments.claim: On proper reading of the will as a whole, clause 5 ceased to be operative after death of Jageshwar Kuer; clause 4 was the only operative clause giving absolute rights to appellant and Sheorani

anchor.surface_text: This contention, as mentioned earlier, did not find favour either with the trial court or with the appellate court. They have held that on a proper reading of the will as a whole, it is clear that clause 5 ceased to be operative on the death of Jageshwar Kuer, thereafter clause 4 of the will was the only operative clause so far as the rights of the appellant and Sheorani were concerned.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ad number happened before the period when the property bequeathed was

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court in agreement with courts below

arguments.claim: Duty of court is to find intention of testator gathered from language of will read as a whole

anchor.surface_text: It is undisputed that the duty of the court is to find out the intention of the testator but that intention has to be gathered from the language of the will read as a whole. It is clear from clause 4 of the will that the testator wanted to give to his grand-daughters an absolute right

arguments.claim: Clause 4 of the will gives granddaughters absolute right/estate in properties devolving after Jageshwar Kuer's death

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from clause 4 of the will that the testator wanted to give to his grand-daughters an absolute right in the properties that were to devolve on them after the death of his wife, Jageshwar Kuer. The estate bequeathed under clause 4 of the will is not a conditional estate.

arguments.claim: Estate bequeathed under clause 4 is not a conditional estate

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from clause 4 of the will that the testator wanted to give to his grand-daughters an absolute right in the properties that were to devolve on them after the death of his wife, Jageshwar Kuer. The estate bequeathed under clause 4 of the will is not a conditional estate.

arguments.claim: Clause 5 relates to devolution and does not provide for divestment of vested estate; estate vested absolutely on Sheorani

anchor.surface_text: Clause 5 of the will relates to devolution and it does not provide for any divestment of an estate which had vested. The estate that vested on Sheorani was an absolute one. The will does not provide for the divestment of that estate.

arguments.claim: There is no conflict between clause 4 and clause 5 of the will

anchor.surface_text: We are, unable to accept the contention of Mr. M. C. Chagla, learned Counsel for the appellant that there is a conflict between clause 4 and clause 5 of the will.

arguments.claim: Clause 5 would have come into force if contingency happened before properties devolved/absolutely vested on the two sisters

anchor.surface_text: Clause 5 in our judgment would have come into force if the contingency mentioned therein had happened before the properties absolutely devolved on the two sisters.

arguments.claim: Clause 5 cannot be considered as a defeasance clause

anchor.surface_text: Clause 5 cannot be considered as a defeasance clause. If the testator wanted that the bequest made to any of his grand- daughters should stand divested on the happening of any contingency, then he would have said so in the will

arguments.claim: To find effect of will, look to ss. 1-4 and 131 of Indian Succession Act 1925

anchor.surface_text: To find out the effect of the will before us we have to look to ss. 1-4 and 131 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925.

arguments.claim: Section 124 ISA applies; legacy to appellant unavailable as uncertain event did not happen before fund payable/distributable

anchor.surface_text: Section 124 says Where a legacy is given if a specified uncertain event shall happen and no time is mentioned in the will for the occurrence of that event, the legacy cannot take effect, unless such event happens before the period when the fund bequeathed is payable or distributable... If s. 124 applies to the facts of the case, as we think it does, then it is clear that the legacy claimed by the appellant is unavailable

arguments.claim: Governing provision is not S. 131 as it deals with divestment of vested estate but clause 5 is not defeasance

anchor.surface_text: Section 124 deals with devolution. But as we shall presently see s. 131 deals with divestment of an estate that had vested... Mr. Chagla contends that the governing provision is S. 131. That section says A bequest may be made to any person with the condition super added that, in case a specified uncertain event shall happen, the thing bequeathed shall go to another person... As seen earlier clause 5 of the will is not a defeasance clause.

arguments.claim: Privy Council case Norendra Nath Sircar v. Kamal Basini Dasi is analogous, applying s.111 ISA 1865 (similar to s.124 ISA 1925)

anchor.surface_text: A case somewhat similar to the one before us came up for consideration before the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Norendra Nath Sircar and anr. v. Kamal Basini Dasi... In arriving at this conclusion, the Judicial Committee relied on s. 111 of the Indian Succession Act, 1865. That provision is similar to s. 124 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925.

arguments.claim: The governing provision is S. 131 of Indian Succession Act

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chagla contends that the governing provision is S. 131. That section says A bequest may be made to any person with the condition

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ber take effect. If s. 124 applies to the facts of the case, as we think it does, then it is clear that the legacy claimed by the appellant is unavail

arguments.court_reasoning: S.131 deals with divestment after vesting but clause 5 not defeasance clause and relates to devolution

arguments.claim: There is a conflict between clause 4 and clause 5 of the will

anchor.surface_text: We are, unable to accept the contention of Mr. M. C. Chagla, learned Counsel for the appellant that there is a conflict between clause 4 and clause 5 of the will.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ted. The estate that vested on Sheorani was an absolute one. The will does number provide for the divestment of that estate. It is plain from the lang

arguments.court_reasoning: Clause 5 operative only if contingency before vesting under clause 4; no conflict on harmonious reading

holdings.text: The suit brought by the appellant is unsustainable as she is not entitled to Sheorani's share under clause 5 of the will.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above we are in agreement with the courts below that the suit brought by the appellant is un- sustainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Will read as whole shows clause 4 vested absolute estate post-Jageshwar death; clause 5 concerns prior devolution only; S.124 ISA applies as contingency post-distribution.

holdings.text: Clause 4 of the will bequeaths an absolute estate to the granddaughters in equal shares, not a conditional estate.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from clause 4 of the will that the testator wanted to give to his grand-daughters an absolute right in the properties that were to devolve on them after the death of his wife, Jageshwar Kuer. The estate bequeathed under clause 4 of the will is not a conditional estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intention gathered from language of clause 4 read in context of whole will giving absolute proprietary interest post-life interest.

holdings.text: Clause 5 relates to devolution of property and does not provide for divestment of a vested absolute estate.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 5 of the will relates to devolution and it does not provide for any divestment of an estate which had vested. The estate that vested on Sheorani was an absolute one. The will does not provide for the divestment of that estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Language of clause 5 refers to devolution on Jageshwar's death; absolute vesting occurred then, no divestment clause present.

holdings.text: There is no conflict between clause 4 and clause 5 of the will.

anchor.surface_text: We are, unable to accept the contention of Mr. M. C. Chagla, learned Counsel for the appellant that there is a conflict between clause 4 and clause 5 of the will.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading: clause 5 applies pre-vesting contingency; clause 4 vests absolute post-devolution.

holdings.text: Clause 5 would have operated if the contingency (death issueless) occurred before properties devolved on the granddaughters.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 5 in our judgment would have come into force if the contingency mentioned therein had happened before the properties absolutely devolved on the two sisters.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Timing of contingency critical; post-vesting death of Sheorani issueless does not trigger clause 5.

holdings.text: Clause 5 is not a defeasance clause providing for divestment on contingency.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 5 cannot be considered as a defeasance clause. If the testator wanted that the bequest made to any of his grand- daughters should stand divested on the happening of any contingency, then he would have said so in the will

holdings.reasoning_summary: No language indicating divestment of vested property; testator would have explicitly stated if intended.

holdings.text: Section 124 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925 applies; the contingent legacy to appellant fails as event did not occur before distribution.

anchor.surface_text: If s. 124 applies to the facts of the case, as we think it does, then it is clear that the legacy claimed by the appellant is unavailable as the contemplated contingency did not occur before the fund bequeathed was payable or distributable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of S.124 to facts: contingency post-period of distribution after Jageshwar death.

holdings.text: Section 131 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925 is not the governing provision as clause 5 does not provide for divestment of vested estate.

anchor.surface_text: Section 124 deals with devolution. But as we shall presently see s. 131 deals with divestment of an estate that had vested... Mr. Chagla contends that the governing provision is S. 131... As seen earlier clause 5 of the will is not a defeasance clause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.131 requires superadded condition for divestment post-vesting; clause 5 concerns pre-vesting devolution only.

holdings.text: The Privy Council decision in Norendra Nath Sircar v. Kamal Basini Dasi is analogous and supports application of S.124-like provision.

anchor.surface_text: A case somewhat similar to the one before us came up for consideration before the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Norendra Nath Sircar and anr. v. Kamal Basini Dasi... In arriving at this conclusion, the Judicial Committee relied on s. 111 of the Indian Succession Act, 1865. That provision is similar to s. 124 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Similar will clause interpreted as contingent legacy failing if event post-distribution; relies on predecessor statute.

precedents.cited_proposition: words in a will giving property to sons equally, with provision that if any son dies sonless the surviving son takes all, constitute a contingent legacy to survivors on specified uncertain event of death without issue before distribution, which did not happen
precedents.cited_holding: those words gave a legacy to the survivors contingently on the happening of a specified uncertain event, which had number happened before the period when the property bequeathed was distributable, that period of distribution being the time of the testators death
